What is your overall assessment of this course?

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course will introduce you to contemporary debates in the field of critical theory. It also provides a lot of intellectual history of twentieth century German critical theory.
Thinking about and critiquing capitalism and neoliberalism. Reading dense philosophical texts and understanding them.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is extremely fascinating, covering interesting debates and readings, and Professor Benhabib is remarkably insightful and enlightening. If you are interested in critical theory or contemporary political theory, you will be interested, however oftentimes the themes throughout the course feel weak, and it can be hard to take away clear conclusions or ideas from many of the discussions.

Strengths: Incredible professor, Prof Benhabib is a brilliant lecturer who clarifies complex concepts eloquently
Weaknesses: Not as much discussion time as I would have liked, but that may be a function of the lecture-seminar format and Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Nothing in particular needed to be improved.
The use of powerpoint for lectures was very helpful and made zoom presentations by classmates easy to follow.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Take this course if you are interested in critical theory or contemporary critiques of political economy or political theory. However be prepared to sometimes feel lost both in specific discussions with intellectual barriers to entry, as well as broadly in understanding the arc of the course and synthesizing central currents.

Absolutely would recommend this course to anyone passionate about critical theory and who is looking for a good primer on key arguments over capitalism and neoliberalism and the crisis times we live in

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
